name: Garden of the Gods
description: This iconic area features several interconnected trails, with the centerpiece being the rock formations known as the Garden of the Gods. The most popular trail is the Garden of the Gods Observation Trail, an easy 0.5-mile loop that provides stunning views of the unique sandstone formations.

name: Cache River State
park: Lake Clark National Park and Preserve
description: This 7-mile loop trail can be shortened to various lengths. It offers a unique experience, making you feel like you're in a Louisiana cypress swamp. The trail features elevated walkways through wetlands, providing opportunities to observe diverse wildlife.

name: Panther Den Loop
park: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park
description: Located south of Carbondale near Devil's Kitchen Lake, this hidden gem is popular among locals. The trail offers views of wildflowers, rock outcroppings, and abundant wildlife. It's approximately 3 miles long with an elevation change of about 160 feet.

name: Little Grand Canyon
description: This 3-mile loop trail in Shawnee National Forest is considered moderate to strenuous. The highlight is descending into and climbing through the canyon, offering a diverse and challenging hiking experience.

name: Rim Rock Trail
park: Lake Clark National Park and Preserve
description: Located in Shawnee National Forest, this 1.7-mile loop trail is moderately rugged and features high bluffs, waterfalls, natural shelters, scenic creeks, and even a Native American rock wall. It also provides access to Pounds Hollow beach.

name: Ferne Clyffe Waterfall
description: This easy 1.3-mile out-and-back trail in Ferne Clyffe State Park leads to a beautiful waterfall. It's family-friendly and perfect for a picnic, with benches along the trail.

name: Red Cedar Trail at Giant City
park: Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve
description: For more experienced hikers, this 12-mile loop trail is one of the most challenging in the area. It features massive rock outcroppings, deep forests, small waterfalls, and diverse terrain. It's often used for backpacking or multi-day hikes.

name: North Cedar Lake Trail
description: SThis trail near Carbondale is approximately 9.7 km long and has the most elevation gain (132 m) of all trails in the immediate area.
